column1: #Text=Spanish King 's ' shut up ' to Chávez becomes ringtone
#Text=The angry " Why do n't you shut up ? "
#Text=that King Juan Carlos I of Spain uttered against Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez a week ago on Saturday has apparently reached a cult status in Spain and Venezuela .
#Text=A mobile phone ringtone remix of the quote text has been downloaded 500,000 times ( generating some € 1.5 million revenues ) .
#Text=The ringtone features a voice actor ( avoiding legal issues ) with beats and a loop effect emphasising the ' shut up ' .
#Text=A student group from the Venezuelan capital of Caracas which opposes the President has downloaded the ringtone too .
#Text=" It 's a form of protest , it 's something that a lot of people would like to tell the president .

#Text=At the Ibero-American summit in Santiago , Chile on November 10 , Chávez called the Spain 's former prime minister , José María Aznar , a  fascist " .

column1: #Text=Current Prime Minister of Spain José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero tried to reply , but Chávez , although his microphone was switched off , kept interrupting him .
#Text=The Spanish King first pointed a finger at Mr. Chávez , with the words " Y tu " ( and you ) .
#Text=Then , while Zapatero still tried to reply , he said “ ¿ Por qué no te callas ? ” while making a gesture with his hand .
#Text=Note that the King used the informal ' te callas ' instead of the formal and polite third-person form .
#Text=Zapatero finally replied that " ... in a forum where there are democratic governments ...
